Description: Body sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery lekane; white slip; interior: painted decoration consisting of animal (part of head with eye and possibly neck with added red remaining); pendant triangle and other undetermined motif as filling ornament; exterior: goat (back, under belly, rump, tail and hind legs remaining) to right; complex rosette as filling ornament.
Producer name: Attributed to: Group of the Aphrodite Bowl (possibly)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The placement of the elaborate rosette is the same as that on the Aphrodite Bowl. Though possibly not by the painter of the Aphrodite Bowl himself, this sherd fits into Lemos's Group of the Aphrodite Bowl. Lemos describes the interior decoration on the sherd as a goose, but the type of eye depicted is not seen on geese and is more typical of goats. However, if this is a goat, its position is unclear, as it would appear that its neck is twisted in a highly unatural manner.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 34, no. 123, pl. 31)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 244, no. 257, pl. 29)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 132 note 26)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2060) (phase 2)
